%mdk-data-line={145}
\noindent\mdline{145}This document briefly summarizes current formal method groups, proof
systems, projects and researchers. For each it gives pointers for
further information. It is a work-in-progress and is necessarily
incomplete.%mdk

\subsection{\mdline{161}2.3.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{161}Yale FLINT Group}\label{sec-yale-flint-group}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={162}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={162}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{162}\href{http://flint.cs.yale.edu/flint/}{{\ttfamily http://\hspace{0pt}flint.\hspace{0pt}cs.\hspace{0pt}yale.\hspace{0pt}edu/\hspace{0pt}flint/\hspace{0pt}}}\mdline{162}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Publications}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={164}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{164}\href{http://flint.cs.yale.edu/flint/publications}{{\ttfamily http://\hspace{0pt}flint.\hspace{0pt}cs.\hspace{0pt}yale.\hspace{0pt}edu/\hspace{0pt}flint/\hspace{0pt}publications}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={167}
\noindent\mdline{167}"\mdline{167}The FLINT group at Yale aims to develop a novel and practical
programming infrastructure for constructing large-scale certified
systems software. By combining recent new advances in programming
languages, formal semantics, certified operating systems, program
verification, proof assistants and automation, language-based
secrurity, and certifying compilers, we hope to attack the following
research questions:%mdk

%mdk-data-line={175}
\begin{itemize}[noitemsep,topsep=\mdcompacttopsep]%mdk

%mdk-data-line={175}
\item\mdline{175}what system software structures can offer the best support for extensibility, security, and resilience?%mdk

%mdk-data-line={176}
\item\mdline{176}what program logics and semantic models can best capture these abstractions?%mdk

%mdk-data-line={177}
\item\mdline{177}what are the right programming languages and environments for developing such certified system software?%mdk

%mdk-data-line={178}
\item\mdline{178}how to build new automation facilities to make certified software really scale?\mdline{178}"\mdline{178}%mdk
%mdk
\end{itemize}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={190}
\mdline{190}Everest is a recursive acronym: It stands for the “Everest VERified
End-to-end Secure Transport”.\mdline{191}"\mdline{191}%mdk

\section{\mdline{199}3.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{199}Formal Methods Proof Systems}\label{sec-formal-methods-proof-systems}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={200}
\subsection{\mdline{200}3.1.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{200}Coq}\label{sec-coq}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={201}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={201}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{201}\href{https://coq.inria.fr/}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}coq.\hspace{0pt}inria.\hspace{0pt}fr/\hspace{0pt}}}\mdline{201}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={203}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{203}\href{https://github.com/coq/coq.git}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}com/\hspace{0pt}coq/\hspace{0pt}coq.\hspace{0pt}git}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={206}
\noindent\mdline{206}Coq is a formal proof management system. It provides a formal language
to write mathematical definitions, executable algorithms and theorems
together with an environment for semi-interactive development of
machine-checked proofs. Typical applications include the certification
of properties of programming languages (e.g. the CompCert compiler
certification project, or the Bedrock verified low-level programming
library), the formalization of mathematics (e.g. the full
formalization of the Feit-Thompson theorem or homotopy type theory)
and teaching.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={225}
\subsection{\mdline{225}3.3.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{225}Isabelle}\label{sec-isabelle}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={226}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={226}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{226}\href{https://isabelle.in.tum.de/}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}isabelle.\hspace{0pt}in.\hspace{0pt}tum.\hspace{0pt}de/\hspace{0pt}}}\mdline{226}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={228}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{228}hg clone \mdline{228}\href{https://isabelle.in.tum.de/repos/isabelle}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}isabelle.\hspace{0pt}in.\hspace{0pt}tum.\hspace{0pt}de/\hspace{0pt}repos/\hspace{0pt}isabelle}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={231}
\noindent\mdline{231}\textquotedblleft{}Isabelle is a generic proof assistant. It allows mathematical
formulas to be expressed in a formal language and provides tools for
proving those formulas in a logical calculus. The main application is
the formalization of mathematical proofs and in particular formal
verification, which includes proving the correctness of computer
hardware or software and proving properties of computer languages and
protocols.\textquotedblright{}\mdline{237}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={239}
\subsection{\mdline{239}3.4.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{239}HOL4}\label{sec-hol4}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={240}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={240}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{240}\href{https://hol-theorem-prover.org/}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}hol-\hspace{0pt}theorem-\hspace{0pt}prover.\hspace{0pt}org/\hspace{0pt}}}\mdline{240}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={242}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{242}\href{https://github.com/HOL-Theorem-Prover}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}com/\hspace{0pt}HOL-\hspace{0pt}Theorem-\hspace{0pt}Prover}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={245}
\noindent\mdline{245}\textquotedblleft{}The HOL interactive theorem prover is a proof assistant for
higher-order logic: a programming environment in which theorems can be
proved and proof tools implemented. Built-in decision procedures and
theorem provers can automatically establish many simple theorems
(users may have to prove the hard theorems themselves!) An oracle
mechanism gives access to external programs such as SMT and BDD
engines. HOL is particularly suitable as a platform for implementing
combinations of deduction, execution and property checking.\textquotedblright{}\mdline{252}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={254}
\subsection{\mdline{254}3.5.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{254}HOL-Light}\label{sec-hol-light}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={255}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={255}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{255}\href{https://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~jrh13/hol-light/}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}www.\hspace{0pt}cl.\hspace{0pt}cam.\hspace{0pt}ac.\hspace{0pt}uk/\hspace{0pt}\textasciitilde{}jrh13/\hspace{0pt}hol-\hspace{0pt}light/\hspace{0pt}}}\mdline{255}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={257}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{257}\href{https://github.com/jrh13/hol-light/}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}com/\hspace{0pt}jrh13/\hspace{0pt}hol-\hspace{0pt}light/\hspace{0pt}}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={260}
\noindent\mdline{260}\textquotedblleft{}HOL Light is a computer program to help users prove interesting
mathematical theorems completely formally in higher order logic. It
sets a very exacting standard of correctness, but provides a number of
automated tools and pre-proved mathematical theorems (e.g. about
arithmetic, basic set theory and real analysis) to save the user
work. It is also fully programmable, so users can extend it with new
theorems and inference rules without compromising its soundness.\textquotedblright{}\mdline{266}%mdk

\section{\mdline{308}4.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{308}Formal Methods Projects}\label{sec-formal-methods-projects}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={310}
\subsection{\mdline{310}4.1.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{310}DeepSpec Projects}\label{sec-deepspec-projects}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={311}
\subsubsection{\mdline{311}4.1.1.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{311}CompCert}\label{sec-compcert}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={312}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={312}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{312}\href{http://compcert.inria.fr}{{\ttfamily http://\hspace{0pt}compcert.\hspace{0pt}inria.\hspace{0pt}fr}}\mdline{312}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={314}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{314}\href{https://github.com/AbsInt/CompCert.git}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}com/\hspace{0pt}AbsInt/\hspace{0pt}CompCert.\hspace{0pt}git}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={317}
\noindent\mdline{317}The CompCert C verified compiler is a compiler for a large subset of
the C programming language that generates code for the PowerPC, ARM,
x86 and RISC-V processors.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={321}
\mdline{321}The distinguishing feature of CompCert is that it has been formally
verified using the Coq proof assistant: the generated assembly code is
formally guaranteed to behave as prescribed by the semantics of the
source C code.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={326}
\subsubsection{\mdline{326}4.1.2.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{326}Verified Software Toolchain}\label{sec-verified-software-toolchain}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={327}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={327}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{327}\href{http://vst.cs.princeton.edu/}{{\ttfamily http://\hspace{0pt}vst.\hspace{0pt}cs.\hspace{0pt}princeton.\hspace{0pt}edu/\hspace{0pt}}}\mdline{327}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={329}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{329}\href{https://github.com/PrincetonUniversity/VST.git}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}com/\hspace{0pt}PrincetonUniversity/\hspace{0pt}VST.\hspace{0pt}git}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={332}
\noindent\mdline{332}The software toolchain includes static analyzers to check assertions
about your program; optimizing compilers to translate your program to
machine language; operating systems and libraries to supply context
for your program. The Verified Software Toolchain project assures with
machine-checked proofs that the assertions claimed at the top of the
toolchain really hold in the machine-language program, running in the
operating-system context.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={340}
\mdline{340}In some application domains it is not enough to build reliable
software systems, one wants proved-correct software. This is the case
for safety-critical systems (where software bugs can cause injury or
death) and for security-critical applications (where an attacker is
deliberately searching for, and exploiting, software bugs). Since
proofs are large and complex, the proof-checking must be
mechanized. Machine-checked proofs of real software systems are
difficult, but now should be possible, given the recent advances in
the theory and engineering of mechanized proof systems applied to
software verification. But there are several challenges:%mdk

%mdk-data-line={351}
\begin{itemize}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={351}
\item{}
%mdk-data-line={351}
\mdline{351}Real software systems are usually built from components in different
programming languages.%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={354}
\item{}
%mdk-data-line={354}
\mdline{354}Some parts of the program need full correctness proofs, which must
be constructed with great effort; other parts need only safety
proofs, which can be constructed automatically.%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={358}
\item{}
%mdk-data-line={358}
\mdline{358}One reasons about correctness at the source-code level, but one runs
a machine-code program translated by a compiler; the compiler must
be proved correct.%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={362}
\item{}
%mdk-data-line={362}
\mdline{362}These proofs about different properties, with respect to different
programming languages, must be integrated together end-to-end in a
way that is also proved correct and machine-checked.%mdk%mdk
%mdk
\end{itemize}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={366}
\noindent\mdline{366}We address these challenges by defining Verifiable C, a program logic
for the C programming language. Verifiable C is proved sound with
respect to the operational semantics of CompCert C; in turn, the
CompCert verified optimizing C compiler is proved correct with respect
to the assembly-language semantics of the PowerPC, ARM, and x86
processors.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={373}
\subsubsection{\mdline{373}4.1.3.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{373}CertiKOS\mdline{373} \mdline{373}- Certified Kit Operating System}\label{sec-certikos---certified-kit-operating-system}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={374}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={374}

%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={381}
\subsubsection{\mdline{381}4.1.4.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{381}VeriML}\label{sec-veriml}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={382}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={382}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{382}\href{http://flint.cs.yale.edu/shao/papers/veriml.html}{{\ttfamily http://\hspace{0pt}flint.\hspace{0pt}cs.\hspace{0pt}yale.\hspace{0pt}edu/\hspace{0pt}shao/\hspace{0pt}papers/\hspace{0pt}veriml.\hspace{0pt}html}}\mdline{382}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={384}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{384}\href{http://flint.cs.yale.edu/flint/publications/veriml-0.1.tar.gz}{{\ttfamily http://\hspace{0pt}flint.\hspace{0pt}cs.\hspace{0pt}yale.\hspace{0pt}edu/\hspace{0pt}flint/\hspace{0pt}publications/\hspace{0pt}veriml-\hspace{0pt}0.\hspace{0pt}1.\hspace{0pt}tar.\hspace{0pt}gz}}\mdline{384}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Paper}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={386}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{386}\href{http://flint.cs.yale.edu/flint/publications/verimltr.pdf}{{\ttfamily http://\hspace{0pt}flint.\hspace{0pt}cs.\hspace{0pt}yale.\hspace{0pt}edu/\hspace{0pt}flint/\hspace{0pt}publications/\hspace{0pt}verimltr.\hspace{0pt}pdf}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={389}
\noindent\mdline{389}Developed by the FLINT group.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={391}
\mdline{391}Modern proof assistants such as Coq and Isabelle provide high degrees
of expressiveness and assurance because they support formal reasoning
in higher-order logic and supply explicit machine-checkable proof
objects. Unfortunately, large scale proof development in these proof
assistants is still an extremely difficult and time-consuming
task. One major weakness of these proof assistants is the lack of a
single language where users can develop complex tactics and decision
procedures using a rich programming model and in a typeful
manner. This limits the scalability of the proof development process,
as users avoid developing domain-specific tactics and decision
procedures.
¯˘
In this paper, we present VeriML\mdline{403}\textemdash{}\mdline{403}a novel language design that
couples a type-safe effectful computational language with first-class
support for manipulating logical terms such as propositions and
proofs. The main idea behind our design is to integrate a rich logical
framework\mdline{407}\textemdash{}\mdline{407}similar to the one supported by Coq\mdline{407}\textemdash{}\mdline{407}inside a
computational language inspired by ML. The language design is such
that the added features are orthogonal to the rest of the
computational language, and also do not require significant additions
to the logic language, so soundness is guaranteed. We have built a
prototype implementation of VeriML including both its type-checker and
an interpreter. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our design by
showing a number of type-safe tactics and decision procedures written
in VeriML.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={417}
\subsubsection{\mdline{417}4.1.5.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{417}Certifying Low-Level Programs with Hardware Interrupts and Preemptive Threads}\label{sec-certifying-low-level-programs-with-hardware-interrupts-and-preemptive-threads}%mdk%mdk

\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={433}
\noindent\mdline{433}Kami is a library that turns Coq into an IDE for digital hardware
development, based on a clean-slate reimplementation of a core of the
\mdline{435}\href{http://www.bluespec.com}{Bluespec}\mdline{435} language. We span the gap from mathematical specifications to
hardware circuit descriptions (RTL netlists). We support specifying,
implementing, verifying, and compiling hardware, reasoning at a high
level about particular hardware components but in the end deriving
first-principles Coq theorems about circuits. No part of Kami need be
trusted beside the formalization of low-level (Verilog-style) circuit
descriptions; all other aspects have end-to-end correctness proofs
checked by Coq. Hardware designs are broken into separately verified
modules, reasoned about with a novel take on labeled transition
systems. Furthermore, Coq provides a natural and expressive platform
for metaprogramming, or building verified circuit generators, as for a
memory caching system autogenerated for a particular shape of cache
hierarchy, or a CPU generated given a number of concurrent cores as
input.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={450}
\subsubsection{\mdline{450}4.1.7.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{450}Haskell Core Spec}\label{sec-haskell-core-spec}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={451}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={451}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{451}\href{https://deepspec.org/entry/Project/Haskell+CoreSpec}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}deepspec.\hspace{0pt}org/\hspace{0pt}entry/\hspace{0pt}Project/\hspace{0pt}Haskell+\hspace{0pt}CoreSpec}}\mdline{451}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={453}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{453}\href{https://github.com/sweirich/corespec.git}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}com/\hspace{0pt}sweirich/\hspace{0pt}corespec.\hspace{0pt}git}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={456}
\noindent\mdline{456}The Haskell CoreSpec Project aims to develop formal specifications for
a high-level, industrially-relevant functional programming
language. In particular, this project targets the core language of the
Glasgow Haskell Compiler, the primary compiler for the Haskell
programming language. GHC has long been used as both an industrial
strength compiler and a platform for language research. The compiler
itself is open source, and has primarily been developed and is
currently maintained by researchers at Microsoft Research,
Cambridge. The CoreSpec project will develop a formal Coq
specification of the GHC Core language, including the syntax, type
system, and semantics, and connect that specification to other
components of the DeepSpec project.%mdk

\noindent\mdline{476}\textquotedblleft{}For a final demo, unifying many of the Expedition threads, we aim to

%mdk-data-line={479}
\mdline{479}Status: \mdline{479}\textquotedblleft{}A team at Penn has begun exploring the design space and
building a first-draft prototype (for now, running on Linux) of a web
server library loosely based on the popular libmicrohttpd.  The goal
of this short-term effort is to understand the integration issues that
will be involved in putting together a fully functional server from
components under development within DeepSpec.  In particular, we want
to understand what demands it will place on CertiKOS in terms of OS
features (IPC, network support, shared-memory processes,
interoperation between native clients and Linux VMs), what
verification challenges it raises for VST, what integration challenges
it poses for using VST and CertiKOS together.\textquotedblright{}\mdline{489}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={515}
\noindent\mdline{515}"\mdline{515}The Vellvm project is building a (verified LLVM), a framework for
reasoning about programs expressed in LLVM\mdline{516}'\mdline{516}s intermediate
representation and transformations that operate on it. Vellvm provides
a mechanized formal semantics of LLVM\mdline{518}'\mdline{518}s intermediate representation,
its type system, and properties of its SSA form. The framework is
built using the Coq interactive theorem prover. It includes multiple
operational semantics and proves relations among them to facilitate
different reasoning styles and proof techniques.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={524}
\paragraph{\mdline{524}4.1.10.1.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{524}Latest Results}\label{sec-latest-results}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={526}
\noindent\mdline{526}During the first year of DeepSpec we%mdk

%mdk-data-line={528}
\begin{enumerate}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={528}
\item{}
%mdk-data-line={528}
\mdline{528}worked on developing a new modular semantics for Vellvm, factoring out the memory model%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={530}
\item{}
%mdk-data-line={530}
\mdline{530}made progress on connecting LLVM-IR like SSA semantics with higher-level structural operational semantics%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={532}
\item{}
%mdk-data-line={532}
\mdline{532}applied low-level language verification techniques to the problem of race detectection instrumentation\mdline{532}"\mdline{532}%mdk%mdk
%mdk
\end{enumerate}%mdk

\noindent\mdline{543}\textquotedblleft{}We are pursuing end-to-end proofs of cryptographic functionality, via
verification of C code at Princeton and synthesis of assembly code at
MIT.  We are considering both cryptographic primitives
(e.g. pseudorandom number generation with VST at Princeton and
elliptic curve operations with fiat-crypto at MIT) and protocols
(verified with the Foundational Cryptography Framework and connected
to results about C and assembly programs).\textquotedblright{}\mdline{549}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={551}
\paragraph{\mdline{551}Latest Results:}\label{sec-latest-results-}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={553}
\noindent\mdline{553}Fiat Cryptography is now used in Google\mdline{553}'\mdline{553}s BoringSSL library for
elliptic-curve arithmetic.  As a result, Chrome HTTPS connections now
run our Coq-generated code.  Our  upcoming S\mdline{555}\&\mdline{555}P 2019 paper goes into
more detail.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={558}
\mdline{558}VST verification has recently focused on the primitives HMAC-DGBG and
HKDF\mdline{559} \mdline{559}\textendash{}\mdline{559} both clients of HMAC/SHA256, AES, and parts of the TweetNaCl
library. In addition to verifying (families of) primitives, we hope to
soon turn to integration in larger contexts like verified TLS
libraries.%mdk

\subsubsection{\mdline{573}4.1.13.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{573}Fiat}\label{sec-fiat}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={574}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={574}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{574}\href{http://plv.csail.mit.edu/fiat/}{{\ttfamily http://\hspace{0pt}plv.\hspace{0pt}csail.\hspace{0pt}mit.\hspace{0pt}edu/\hspace{0pt}fiat/\hspace{0pt}}}\mdline{574}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={576}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{576}\href{https://github.com/mit-plv/fiat.git}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}com/\hspace{0pt}mit-\hspace{0pt}plv/\hspace{0pt}fiat.\hspace{0pt}git}}\mdline{576}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Papers}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={578}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{578}\href{https://www.cs.purdue.edu/homes/bendy/Fiat/fiat-snapl.pdf}{The End of History? Using a Proof Assistant to
Replace Language Design with Library Design}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={582}
\noindent\mdline{582}\textquotedblleft{}Fiat is a library for the Coq proof assistant for synthesizing
efficient correct-by-construction programs from declarative
specifications. Programming by Fiat starts with a high-level
description of a program, which can be written using libraries of
specification languages for describing common programming tasks like
querying a relational database. These specifications are then
iteratively refined into efficient implementations via automated
tactics. Each derivation in Fiat produces a formal proof trail
certifying that the synthesized program meets the original
specification. Code synthesized by Fiat can be extracted to an
equivalent OCaml program that can be compiled and run as normal.\textquotedblright{}\mdline{592}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={609}
\subsubsection{\mdline{609}4.1.15.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{609}Bedrock2}\label{sec-bedrock2}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={610}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={610}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{610}\href{https://github.com/mit-plv/bedrock2}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}com/\hspace{0pt}mit-\hspace{0pt}plv/\hspace{0pt}bedrock2}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={613}
\noindent\mdline{613}\textquotedblleft{}The Bedrock2 repository contains ongoing work on a low-level systems
programming language. One piece of the puzzle is a verified compiler
targeting RISC-V. The source language itself is also equipped with a
simple program logic for proving correctness of the source
programs. It is not ready yet, at least for most uses.  This project
has similar goals as bedrock, but uses a different design. No code is
shared between bedrock and bedrock2.
The source language is a \textquotedblright{}\mdline{620}C-like\mdline{620}\textquotedblleft{} language called ExprImp.\textquotedblright{}\mdline{620}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={622}
\subsubsection{\mdline{622}4.1.16.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{622}CertiCoq}\label{sec-certicoq}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={623}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={623}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{623}\href{https://www.cs.princeton.edu/~appel/certicoq/}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}www.\hspace{0pt}cs.\hspace{0pt}princeton.\hspace{0pt}edu/\hspace{0pt}\textasciitilde{}appel/\hspace{0pt}certicoq/\hspace{0pt}}}\mdline{623}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Source}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={625}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{625}\href{https://github.com/PrincetonUniversity/certicoq}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}com/\hspace{0pt}PrincetonUniversity/\hspace{0pt}certicoq}}\mdline{625}
%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Paper}}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={627}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{627}\href{http://www.cs.princeton.edu/~appel/papers/certicoq-coqpl.pdf}{{\ttfamily http://\hspace{0pt}www.\hspace{0pt}cs.\hspace{0pt}princeton.\hspace{0pt}edu/\hspace{0pt}\textasciitilde{}appel/\hspace{0pt}papers/\hspace{0pt}certicoq-\hspace{0pt}coqpl.\hspace{0pt}pdf}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={630}
\noindent\mdline{630}\textquotedblleft{}The CertiCoq project aims to build a proven-correct compiler for
dependently-typed, functional languages, such as Gallinathe core
language of the Coq proof assistant. A proved-correct compiler
consists of a high-level functional specification, machine-verified
proofs of important properties, such as safety and correctness, and a
mechanism to transport those proofs to the generated machine code. The
project exposes both engineering challenges and foundational questions
about compilers for dependently-typed languages.\textquotedblright{}\mdline{637}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={639}
\subsubsection{\mdline{639}4.1.17.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{639}Template-Coq}\label{sec-template-coq}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={640}
\begin{mddefinitions}%mdk

\mddefterm{\noindent{\bfseries Home Page }}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={640}
\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{640}\href{https://template-coq.github.io/template-coq/}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}template-\hspace{0pt}coq.\hspace{0pt}github.\hspace{0pt}io/\hspace{0pt}template-\hspace{0pt}coq/\hspace{0pt}}}\mdline{640}
%mdk

\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk

\begin{mdbmarginx}{}{}{}{1.5em}%mdk
\begin{mddefdata}%mdk
\mdline{644}\href{https://popl18.sigplan.org/event/coqpl-2018-typed-template-coq}{{\ttfamily https://\hspace{0pt}popl18.\hspace{0pt}sigplan.\hspace{0pt}org/\hspace{0pt}event/\hspace{0pt}coqpl-\hspace{0pt}2018-\hspace{0pt}typed-\hspace{0pt}template-\hspace{0pt}coq}}%mdk
\end{mddefdata}%mdk
\end{mdbmarginx}%mdk
%mdk
\end{mddefinitions}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={647}
\noindent\mdline{647}Template Coq is a quoting library for\mdline{647}~\href{http://coq.inria.fr}{Coq}\mdline{647}. It
takes \mdline{648}\mdcode{\small Coq}\mdline{648} terms and constructs a representation of their syntax tree as
a \mdline{649}\mdcode{\small Coq}\mdline{649} inductive data type. The representation is based on the kernel\mdline{649}'\mdline{649}s
term representation.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={652}
\mdline{652}This is used as the first stage of CertiCoq.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={670}
\subsection{\mdline{670}4.2.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{670}Everest Projects}\label{sec-everest-projects}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={671}
\noindent\mdline{671}\href{https://project-everest.github.io}{Project Everest}\mdline{671} is the combination of the following projects.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={673}
\begin{itemize}[noitemsep,topsep=\mdcompacttopsep]%mdk

%mdk-data-line={673}
\item\mdline{673}\href{https://fstar-lang.org}{F*}\mdline{673}, a verification language for effectful programs%mdk

%mdk-data-line={674}
\item\mdline{674}\href{https://mitls.org/}{miTLS}\mdline{674}, reference implementation of the TLS protocol in F\mdline{674}*\mdline{674}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={675}
\item\mdline{675}\href{https://github.com/FStarLang/kremlin}{KreMLin}\mdline{675}, a compiler from a subset of F\mdline{675}*\mdline{675} to C%mdk

%mdk-data-line={676}
\item\mdline{676}\href{https://github.com/mitls/hacl-star}{HACL*}\mdline{676}, a verified library of cryptographic primitives written in F\mdline{676}*\mdline{676}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={677}
\item\mdline{677}\href{https://github.com/project-everest/vale}{Vale}\mdline{677}, a domain-specific language for verified cryptographic primitives in assembly%mdk

%mdk-data-line={678}
\item\mdline{678}\href{https://github.com/project-everest/hacl-star/blob/fstar-master/README.EverCrypt.md}{EverCrypt}\mdline{678}, a verified crypto provider that combines HACL\mdline{678}*\mdline{678} and Vale via an agile, multi-platform, self-configuring cryptographic API.%mdk

%mdk-data-line={679}
\item\mdline{679}\href{https://github.com/project-everest/everparse}{EverParse}\mdline{679}, a library and tool to automatically generate verified parsers and serializers for binary data formats%mdk

%mdk-data-line={680}
\item\mdline{680}\href{https://github.com/project-everest/quackyducky}{Quackyducky}\mdline{680}, a small tool to translate informal specification of
message formats found in RFC (in particular for TLS 1.3) into formal
F\mdline{682}\#\mdline{682} specifications, which are in turn transformed into efficient and
verified parser implementations.%mdk
%mdk
\end{itemize}%mdk

%mdk-data-line={761}
\section{\mdline{761}6.\hspace*{0.5em}\mdline{761}Statistics}\label{sec-statistics}%mdk%mdk

%mdk-data-line={762}
\noindent\mdline{762}Here are some statistics for projects using Coq. The \mdline{762}\textquotedblleft{}Types\textquotedblright{}\mdline{762} column is
the number of inductive types defined. The \mdline{763}\textquotedblleft{}Defs\textquotedblright{}\mdline{763} column is the number
of \mdline{764}\textquotedblleft{}Definitions\textquotedblright{}\mdline{764}. Some projects are broken up by component.%mdk
\begin{mdtabular}{7}{\dimeval{(\linewidth-6cm)/6}}{1ex}%mdk
\begin{tabular}{lrrrrrl}\midrule[\dimpx{2}]
\multicolumn{1}{|l}{{\mdseries\mdline{767} Project}}&\multicolumn{1}{|r}{{\mdseries\mdline{767} \mdline{767}\#\mdline{767}Coq}}&\multicolumn{1}{|r}{{\mdseries\mdline{767} SLOC}}&\multicolumn{1}{|r}{{\mdseries\mdline{767} Proofs}}&\multicolumn{1}{|r}{{\mdseries\mdline{767} Types}}&\multicolumn{1}{|r}{{\mdseries\mdline{767} Defs}}&\multicolumn{1}{c|}{\mdinline{padding-top=3pt,padding-bottom=3pt,width=6cm}{{\mdseries\mdline{767} Notes}}}\\
